posts.message:
I created an open-source app called "Cairo: Streets & Stories"[1], shared by Khaled M. Diab & originally suggested by the journalist Ismail Al Eskandarani. The idea is to convert the book of the same name[2] to an interactive map with rich info & images. It allows end-users to enter the data.

Because of the nature of the app & that Egyptians rarely do crowd-sourcing, my budget for hosting the initial version is zero. Also I will put ads in there, so if the site gets a lot of traffic, it can cover its own hosting  money.

Let's dive in technicality: In the beginning I thought that I would make it a static website hosted on gh-pages & use GitHub for editing geojson, but GitHub uses maps for viewing only, not editing. Also, GitHub is not Egyptian-end-users-friendly.

Now I have to make a dynamic part, so there are the options in my head now

1. Use gh-pages for the front-end & a small back-end to edit geojson & upload images to github. I'm still thinking of the best way to do authentication.

2. Make a dynamic app on AppEngine. I get a free instance, but I will be locked.

3. Make a dynamic app on Heroku (or a similar thing?). I want a free instance with DB storage.

4. What is the best option to store images? Flickr gives 1TB free, but I'm open to suggestions

[1]: https://github.com/mtayseer/cairo_streets_stories
[2]: http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/6289626

MVEL is a very good and cool project if you are using a JVM based language and you want to provide either full scripting language support or just minor predicates parser\interpreter support.
I am using it now, and it is pretty solid.
posts.caption: mvel.codehaus.org
posts.description: MVEL is a powerful expression language for Java-based applications. It provides a plethora of features and is suited for everything from the smallest property binding and extraction, to full blown scripts. For more information, jump right to the Getting Started Guide.

We believe that design does make a difference even if just aesthetics design.

Look at this picture please.

Given a choice between these two petrol stations, do the aesthetics influence which one gets your attention, your trust, your business? Well, the station on the left does not give the confidence that they can handle a customer's credit card securely.

Does your business have a proper design that attracts customers?

Thanks to Alex Mark for this good example (http://www.quora.com/Alex-Mark-2).
